title: 114_s2405
content: The Act may be cited as the "Meth Exposure to the Home Disclosure Act" or the "METH Disclosure Act". Congress finds that there has been a significant increase in methamphetamine laboratory incidents in the United States since 2007. Additionally, only a small percentage of homes used to make methamphetamine are disclosed, leading to environmental contamination. Toxic waste residue from methamphetamine production can linger in buildings for years if not cleaned properly. Harmful by-products like propane, lithium, and solvents can have lasting negative effects on families and children. Contact with these substances can lead to various health issues, including respiratory problems, birth defects, and reproductive issues. Acetone can be fatal, while chronic inhalation of hexane can cause severe damage. Inhalation of hexane can cause damage to the central nervous system, while benzene by-product is linked to anemia and leukemia. Testing for methamphetamine and its harmful by-products is simple and inexpensive. Cleaning a building affected by methamphetamine can cost up to $10,000, posing a financial burden. A law requiring landlords to disclose methamphetamine usage could prevent lethal exposure to millions in the US. The Federal Government needs to take action to protect the health and financial stability of the people in the United States from potentially lethal circumstances. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION CONCERNING THE MANUFACTURE OF METHAMPHETAMINE UPON TRANSFER OR LEASE OF COVERED HOUSING. The term "covered housing" refers to dwelling units and surrounding areas, excluding newly constructed or never occupied housing. A "methamphetamine-based hazard" is a condition causing exposure to harmful substances from methamphetamine production. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will work with other federal agencies to create regulations for disclosing methamphetamine-based hazards in covered housing for sale or lease within 180 days of this Act's enactment. Sellers or lessors must provide a written disclosure before buyers or lessees commit to purchasing or leasing the housing. Sellers or lessors must disclose any knowledge of methamphetamine manufacturing or hazards in covered housing and allow a 10-day period for risk assessment by the purchaser or lessee. Each purchase or lease contract must include a signed statement regarding these disclosures. The covered housing must include a signed statement confirming that the seller or lessor has provided the required disclosures and that the purchaser or lessee had a 10-day opportunity for a risk assessment before committing to the purchase or lease. Compliance assurance is necessary for sellers or lessors in this regard. Compliance assurance is required for sellers or lessors when selling or leasing covered housing, with agents ensuring compliance with regulations. The Secretary has investigative authority to conduct necessary investigations and administer oaths for enforcement. The Secretary has the authority to conduct investigations and administer oaths for enforcement purposes. Any violation of the section will result in penalties for the individual responsible. Individuals found in violation of this section are liable for costs related to remediation of methamphetamine-based hazards in housing, health-related injuries, and attorney's fees for the claimant. They are also subject to civil money penalties as per the Department of Housing regulations. In accordance with the Department of Housing and Urban Development Reform Act of 1989, the Secretary has the authority to take legal action to prevent violations. This section does not affect the validity of contracts, liens, or create defects in title. Regulations under subsection (b)(1) will be effective one year after the enactment of this Act. The Department of Housing and Urban Development Reform Act of 1989 grants the Secretary authority to take legal action to prevent violations. Regulations under subsection (b)(1) will be effective one year after the enactment of this Act. Authorization of appropriations includes $500,000 for fiscal year 2017, $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, and $2,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019, 2020, and 2021.
